questions.question: Question 1: Which among the following is not a premalignant lesion of vulva?
questions.explanation: Condyloma lata is not a premalignant lesion of vulva. Premalignant lesions of the vulva include: • Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) - most common • Paget’s disease • Lichen sclerosus • Squamous cell hyperplasia • Condyloma acuminata • Bowen’s disease (erythroplasia of Querat)

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is a common differential diagnosis of verrucuos carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Condyloma acuminata is the common differential diagnosis of verrucous carcinoma. It refers to anogenital warts and has a verrucous appearance. Verrucous carcinoma is a variant of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. It is locally invasive 
and rarely metastasizes. Condyloma lata is a benign and painless cutaneous manifestation of secondary syphilis. It is 
characterized by gray to white lesions, typically located in the oro-genital region. Chancre is a painless genital ulcer most commonly formed during the primary stage of syphilis.

questions.question:
Question 3: A sexually active woman presents with multiple lesions over her genital region as shown 
below. Which of the following organisms are implicated in this condition? 820 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image are suggestive of genital warts. Human papillomavirus (HPV) 6 and 
11 cause nearly all genital warts. It is usually clinically diagnosed but if co-existing neoplasia is suspected then a biopsy is required. 
HPV serotyping is not required for routine diagnosis.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the earliest symptom in patients with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia?
questions.explanation:
Pruritus is the earliest symptom of VIN as well as vulvar cancer. Clinical features of VIN include: 825 
Sold by @itachibot • Pruritus • White discharge per vagina • Dyspareunia • Vaginal bleeding

questions.question:
Question 5: A woman with vaginal itching is suspected to have vulval intraepithelial neoplasia. Which of 
the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: HPV 16 is the most common cause of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN). Causes of VIN include: • HPV 16, 18, 31, 33 • HSV 2 • Syphilis • Gonorrhea • Gardnerella vaginalis

questions.question:
Question 6: An elderly woman is diagnosed with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia 3. Which of the following 
is false regarding this condition?
questions.explanation:
Elderly women with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) - 3 are HPV negative. VIN 3 is of two types: • Young women – HPV +ve, multiple lesion, 90% regress • Elderly women – HPV –ve, single lesion, associated with lichen sclerosis, often progress to 
invasive cancer

questions.question:
Question 7: 821 
Sold by @itachibot Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological 
malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Among the given gynecological malignancies, sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most useful in 
vulval carcinomas. This is because women with earlier stages of vulval cancer can have diseased lymph nodes even 
without palpable enlargement of nodes. Hence, sentinel lymph node biopsy helps in early 
diagnosis lymph node spread which can be managed by lymph node dissection. A sentinel lymph node is a physiologically, the first lymph node to receive tumor lymphatic 
drainage. Malignancies where sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly done are : • Vulval carcinoma • Breast carcinoma 826 
Sold by @itachibot • Penile carcinoma • Malignant melanoma Lymphatic mapping is similar technique to SLNB that can also be used in vulval cancers.

questions.question: Question 8: Which is most common type of vulval cancer?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulval cancer. Other types of vulval cancer include: • Adenocarcinoma • Melanoma • Basal cell carcinoma • Sarcoma

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the most common type of vaginal cancer likely to be seen in a woman with a history 
of intrauterine di-ethyl stilbesterol exposure?
questions.explanation:
Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is commonly seen in adoloscent girls with a history of 
intrauterine DES exposure. It involves the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Radical hysterectomy, vaginectomy with 
pelvic lymphadenectomy is the treatment of choice. The most common lesion due to DES exposure is vaginal adenosis and not clear cell 
adenocarcinoma. It is a benign condition.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the most common site of vulval cancers?
questions.explanation: The most common site of vulval cancer is labia majora > clitoris > labia minora.

questions.question:
Question 11: 822 
Sold by @itachibot Vulvar carcinoma was diagnosed in a 68-year-old woman who presented with itching and 
mass over the vulva for 6 months. Sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed positive inguinal 
nodes. What is the stage of the tumor?
questions.explanation: According to FIGO staging, tumor with positive inguinal lymph node is classified as stage III.

questions.question:
Question 12: In patients with vulval cancer, what is the least common route through which the malignancy 
spreads?
questions.explanation:
Vascular route of spread is rare in vulval cancer. Lymphatic is the most common route of spread 
in vulval cancer. 827 
Sold by @itachibot Lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor. The sentinel lymph node biopsy is 
helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer. Lymph nodes involved are, superficial inguinal 
nodes (sentinel node) > deep inguinal nodes > femoral group of nodes.

questions.question:
Question 13: An elderly woman is found to have abnormal cells on a pap smear. Further investigations 
reveal vaginal squamous cell carcinoma extending up to the pelvic wall. There is no evidence 
of distant metastasis. What is the stage of the tumor in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Vaginal cancer extending up to the pelvic wall is stage III. Vaginal cancer commonly affects females >70 years of age. Squamous cell carcinoma is the 
most common histologic type. It commonly involves the upper third of the posterior wall of the 
vagina. Patients are mostly asymptomatic. They may present with painless abnormal vaginal bleeding, 
post-coital bleed, and foul-smelling discharge per vagina. Vaginal cancer staging: • Stage 0 - Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia • Stage I - Carcinoma limited to the vaginal wall • Stage II - Carcinoma extending beyond the vagina, but not extending to the pelvic walls • Stage III - Carcinoma extends up to the pelvic walls • Stage IVA - Carcinoma extending beyond the true pelvis/or involving the bladder and/or rectum, 
or evidence of distant metastasis • Stage IVB - Spread to the distant metastasis

questions.question:
Question 14: A 70-year-old presented with a lesion over the vulva as shown below. Bilateral inguinal lymph 
nodes were palpable. Biopsy of the lesion revealed cells containing large, pleomorphic nuclei. 
Which of the following is false regarding this condition? 823 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of vulval melanoma. The most commonly involved site is labia 
majora followed by labia minora and clitoris. Vulval melanoma is the second most common vulval cancer. It may arise from junctional naevus. 
It has a high propensity for local and distant recurrence and has a poor prognosis. Radical vulvectomy and bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment. 828 
Sold by @itachibot Carcinoma Cervix
